head.title: Capturing and Editing Screenshots in Snagit

div.div: Capturing and Editing Screenshots in Snagit

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.div: Capturing and Editing Screenshots in Snagit
This is a list of commonly used Snagit and Snagit Editor keyboard shortcuts.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.div:
Snagit's most basic and essential feature is capturing screenshots. A screenshot is a static picture of your computer screen. Screenshots can add helpful visuals to user documentation. This section will teach you how to capture three different types of screenshots:
Window screenshots
Region screenshots
Scrolling window screenshots

section.p: You can open Snagit on your Windows 10 computer via the Start menu.

li.span: Click on the Start button.
Scroll down the applications list to the TechSmith folder.
Open the TechSmith folder.
Click on Snagit 2021.

div.section: Snagit Capture will open and you can now capture screenshots.

section.p: A window screenshot will capture an image of an entire program. This type of screenshot is quick to capture and usually requires minimal editing.

li.span: Select the Image tab.
Set the Selection type to Window.
Set Effects and Share to None.
Toggle the Capture Cursor option off.
li.div: The toggle icon should be grey when it is turned off.

li.span: Toggle the Preview in Editor option on.
li.div: The toggle icon should be blue when it is turned on.

li.span: Click on Capture.
Click on the window you want to capture.

div.section: Snagit Editor will open up and display the screenshot you captured.

section.p: A region screenshot will only capture the area you select. This type of screenshot is useful when you only need a small portion of the screen or program UI.

li.span: Select the Image tab.
Set the Selection type to Region.
Set Effects and Share to None.
Toggle the Capture Cursor option off.
li.div: The toggle icon should be grey when it is turned off.

li.span: Toggle the Preview in Editor option on.
li.div: The toggle icon should be blue when it is turned on.

li.span: Click on Capture.
Move your mouse to the top corner of the capture area.
Hold down the left mouse button.
Drag the mouse diagonally to the bottom corner of the capture area.
Release the left mouse button.

div.section: Snagit Editor will open up and display the screenshot you captured.

section.p: A scrolling window screenshot will capture the entire width or length of a program's interface. This type of screenshot is useful when you want to capture an entire webpage.

li.span: Find a webpage you want to capture.
Select the Image tab.
Set the Selection type to Scrolling Window.
Set Effects and Share to None.
Toggle the Capture Cursor option off.
li.div: The toggle icon should be grey when it is turned off.

li.span: Toggle the Preview in Editor option on.
li.div: The toggle icon should be blue when it is turned on.

li.span: Click on Capture.
Click on the arrow icon at the bottom of the capture area.

div.section: Snagit will scroll down the window and process the capture. Snagit Editor will display the completed capture.

You are researching Google results to optimize the SEO for our user documentation. After the search results load, you capture a vertically scrolling window screenshot. Snagit processes the image and displays it in Snagit Editor. You can now refer to this screenshot when compiling data about SEO results.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.div:
Snagit has a lot of features that cater to user documentation and tutorial creation. Snagit comes packaged with Snagit Editor, so you can immediately edit your screenshots after capturing them. This section will show you how to perform the most common used editing tasks:
Crop Screenshots
Add Callouts to Screenshots
Resize Screenshots
Save Screenshots

section.p: You can open Snagit Editor while using Snagit Capture.

li.span: Open Snagit Capture.
Click on Open Editor.

figcaption.span: The Open Editor button is underneath the Capture button.

div.section: Snagit Editor will open and display your latest screenshots.

section.p: Cropping your screenshots will make it easier to focus on important information in the screenshot. Cropping can also hide parts of your screen that you want to keep private.

li.span: Open Snagit Editor.
Click on the Library icon.
Double-click on an image to open it.
Click and hold a canvas handle.

figcaption.span: There are eight canvas handles (circled in red) you can drag to crop the image.

li.span: Drag the handle in the direction you want to crop.
Release the handle to stop cropping.
Repeat steps 4-6 until satisfied with the cropped image.

div.section: You now have a cropped screenshot.

section.p: Callouts can bring attention to certain areas of a screenshot. You can add text to callouts to provide additional information to the viewer.

li.span: Open Snagit Editor.
Click on the Library icon.
Double-click on an image to open it.
Open the Image menu.
Hover over the Tools menu.
Click on Callout.
Select a callout shape from the sidebar.
Hold the left mouse button and drag it to adjust the callout size.
Release the mouse button to create the callout.
Type information into the callout.

div.section: You now have a screenshot with an informative callout.

section.p: Sometimes screenshots are too large and need to be resized. You can make screenshots smaller using Snagit Editor's resize tool. It will resample the image when resizing to keep the maximum amount of detail. Resizing to make an image larger should be avoided, since it will become blurry.

li.span: Open Snagit Editor.
Click on the Library icon.
Double-click on an image to open it.
Open the Image menu.
Select the Resize Image... tool.
Enter your desired width in the Width field.
li.div: Snagit Editor will automatically scale the height of the image to match the new width, and vice versa.

li.span: Click on Apply.

div.section: You now have a resized image.

section.p: Snagit Editor automatically saves your captured screenshots as SNAGX files in its library. You should save them to an appropriate location on your computer if you want a traditional image file.

li.span: Open Snagit Editor.
Click on the Library icon.
Double-click on an image to open it.
Open the File menu.
Click on Save As.
Browse to where you want to save the image.
Type in a descriptive name in the File name field.
Select PNG from the Save as type field.
Click on the Save button.

div.section: Your screenshot is now accessible outside of Snagit Editor.
